author: monkeyontheloose.eth
content: Q: after the merge will txns also go to the POW fork mempool? Or does it have a different chain Id?

author: treyzania

author: treyzania

author: monkeyontheloose.eth

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO, the chain ID should change for the branch of the fork that is actually changing code.  I have never liked that it was essentially a marketing contest to see who gets to keep the chain ID and ticker.  I would be much happier if every network upgrade changed the chain ID and ticker, as I think that would make the system for more legitimate.

author: ajsutton
content: The PoW fork is changing code in a number of ways.

author: sky.cactus
content: I assumed that would happen sometime *after* the merge?

author: sky.cactus
content: Seems like you would want to first split off by not merging, then start making changes, rather than making changes at the same time?

author: ajsutton
content: No, from what I've seen so far, they plan to fork ahead of the merge (at a fixed block height) and will be doing things like locking various defi contracts, making EIP1559 base fee pay to the developers and I think a few other things.

author: sky.cactus
content: Any idea what block number?

author: sky.cactus
content: Or where one can find out.

author: ajsutton
content: Not sure - they had a website somewhere I think but it's so hard to tell what's the "real" EthPOW and what's a scam.  It all seems pretty scammy to be honest...

author: sky.cactus
content: I found *a* website a while back but didn't see anything on it about a pre-merge date.

author: sky.cactus
content: It seems quite silly to fork *before* the merge as you are going to be fighting ETH for hashpower.
